title: Subdomain takeover at http://test.www.midigator.com
content:
Vulnerability
Subdomain test.www.midigator.com points to an AWS S3 bucket that no longer exists. I was able to take control of this bucket and serve my own content on it.
Proof Of Concept
Code 315 Bytes
1$ dig test.www.midigator.com
2[snipped]
3;; ANSWER SECTION:
<image_0>
<image_1>
<image_2>
<image_3>
Remediation
Remove the CNAME entry for the test.www.midigator.com
Impact
Subdomain Takeover
steps: Use the dig command to check the DNS records for test.www.midigator.com
Verify that the subdomain points to an AWS S3 bucket that no longer exists
Claim the abandoned S3 bucket and serve custom content
vuln_description: The subdomain test.www.midigator.com was pointing to an AWS S3 bucket that no longer existed, allowing an attacker to claim the bucket and serve malicious content. This is a classic subdomain takeover vulnerability.
reason: This vulnerability is straightforward to discover as it only requires checking DNS records and verifying the availability of the referenced S3 bucket. There are no complex interactions or state manipulations involved.

authnz_metadata.reasoning: The subdomain takeover vulnerability occurs due to a misconfigured DNS CNAME record pointing to an unclaimed AWS S3 bucket. This vulnerability does not involve authentication or authorization bypass within the application's user sessions, resource IDs, or actions. It is an infrastructure configuration issue rather than a flaw in the application's AuthN/AuthZ logic. The described methodologies focus on testing authorization boundaries between users and resources within the application, not DNS or cloud resource ownership validation.
